entry.title: Getting started
entry.content:
In this lesson

In this lesson, we’ll set up our coding environment and talk about the tools that we will use to learn Python. We’ll also have a quick chat about the best strategies to use this course effectively.

  1. Tools overview
    1. The Python interpreter and IDLE
    2. Git and Github
      1. Creating an account
      2. Creating a repository
      3. Setting up Git on your computer to access the repository
      4. Using Git and Github
    3. Other editors
  2. Appendix
    1. Github Education

1. Tools overview

Python doesn’t require much supporting software: the two things we absolutely need are the Python interpreter and a code editor you are comfortable with.

1.1 The Python interpreter and IDLE

This courses uses Python 3.5.x. While you can use previous versions of Python to learn about the language, keep in mind that if you do, syntactic differences will appear along the way that will require you to correct some of the examples. When we will start using third-party modules, the Python version you use will become even more important as different features and module versions are supported by Python 2.7.x and 3.5+. As such, it is strongly recommended to stick with the recommended version.

Regardless of which computer model you have, you can download the Python 3.5+ interpreter here by clicking on the appropriate button.

The Python interpreter download page

The installation package not only contains the interpreter, which will read through our code and execute it, but also IDLE, an easy to use development environment that facilitates writing code and executing it. For the purposes of our course, we will use IDLE as our code editor. If you wish to grow beyond IDLE and use other tools, see Other editors.

No matter the editor you choose to use, once the interpreter is installed, you have access to the interactive Python console. To verify that everything is in working order, you should do the following:

First, open up a command prompt window. If you are running any iteration of Windows, you will find it by looking for Command Prompt, and you can look for Terminal on both OSX and Linux. Once your Command Prompt/Terminal window is open, type in the following:

python

If your interpreter is functional, the interactive console should intialize, showing you which version of Python you are currently using and giving you the opportunity to enter commands.

The interactive Python console

In here, you are able to type any Python statement and see output directly, much like in R or Matlab. We will discuss its usefulness later. To exit the interactive console, simply type exit() and press the return key.

1.2 Git and Github

To keep our code organized, we will use Git. Git is a free and opensource version control system that keeps sharing and keeping track of our projects simple. You can opt to organize your code on your computer as you see fit, but if you choose to use Git, install Git and follow the steps below to create an account and link it to your computer.

We will use Git through the Github, a free service that takes care of maintaining a server on which we can archive our code. To use the service, we will need to create a free account.

1.2.1 Creating an account

Creating a Github account is very simple. First, head to https//www.github.com and fill up the sign up form on the front page. Make sure to use a valid email address as you will have to respond to a validation email to complete the setup.

Github’s signup form

Once you press “Sign up for Github”, you will be taken to the next step: choosing a plan. Github offers paid plans, but for our needs, the free plan is just fine and should be selected by default. If you are currently a student, you most likely quality for the paid version free-of-charge, see the note at the bottom of this page for more details.

Choosing a plan

Once that is done, you should be taken to an optional poll about your programming practice. Feel free to fill it up or to use the “Skip this step” link at the bottom of the form.

Github’s usage poll

Once everything is done, you should receive a confirmation email that will unlock the full potential of your account. Make sure that you click the link that’s on there.

You cannot got further without confirming

1.2.2 Creating repositories

Repositories are containers for your projects. They allow you to group code together based on what you are working on. You can have as many repositories as you desire; today, we will initialize the first one so we can store our course material in it. Once your email is verified, head to your profile by clicking on the “+” located on the top right of the screen and select “New repository”.

Accessing the repository creation form

This will take you to a form defining the basic settings of your repository. Make sure that you do the following:

  1. Choose a meaningful name for your repository (this will be how others and yourself will see it online);
  2. Tick the “Initialize this repository with a README”;
  3. Choose a .gitignore file using the “Add .gitignore” button, you can simply type in Python and use the prebuilt one;

With that done, you can click “Create repository” .

Repository setup

The final step to take on Github’s end is to copy the repository address. This will allow you to create a link between your computer and the repository so you can publish your changes without having to access the website.

Repository address

1.2.3 Setting up Git on your computer to access the repository

Back on Command Prompt or Terminal, you should first type the following to make sure that Git is properly installed:

git --version

If everything is set up correctly, this should display the current version of Git.

You should then navigate to a convenient location to put your Python projects (in this example, we’ll use the My Documents folder):

cd C:\Users\<username>\Documents

Note: On OSX and Linux, this path will be different: /Users/<username>/Documents/ should be equivalent for OSX and /home/<username>/ should be equivalent for Linux

From there, you can clone the repository you created on Github, thereby creating a directory on your computer which is a copy of the Github-hosted version. This is where we’ll store the code we write so we can synchronize the directory with Github’s servers.

git clone <repository address>

Here, <repository address> should have the form https://github.com/<username>/<repository>.git. In the previous examples, the link copied from Github was https://github.com/pythonisbae/firstproject.git.

This will create a directory with the same name as your repository containing your files. You can then access it using cd.

1.2.4 Using Git and Github

At this point, you are ready to use Github! You can test your Git setup by modifying any file in the directory you just created (you can open the README.md file, for example), going back to the Command Prompt/Terminal and using the following commands:

git status

This will show you the current modifications made to the repository. The report should look somewhat like this:

Repository changes

You can then use git add . to add all the files to what you want to synchronize and git commit -m "<message>" to synchronize. Make sure to replace <message> by something meaningful to describe what you changed! This will be useful later when you’ll need to look back at what you’ve done.

Pushing to Github

If all goes well, you should see a synchronization report like the one above. This means that you have successfully uploaded your material to Github. If you go back to your repository’s page on Github’s website, you should now see your updated file(s).

1.3 Other editors

If you want to explore the other editors available on the web and use something else than IDLE, you should check out the editors below. All of them are free and have a rich set of features.

  • Atom
  • Visual Studio Code
  • PyCharm Community Edition

Appendix

Github Education

If you are enrolled as a student, you qualify for Github’s education package. Simply sign up here and enjoy a set of free code-related perks!

entry.title: Python basics
entry.content:
In this lesson

In this lesson, we will look at the interactive Python console. We will explore the notion of variables and methods, and review definitions that will follow us for the rest of our adventure.

  1. Using the interactive console
  2. Variables
    1. Primitives and Objects
    2. Creating and modifying variables

1. Using the interactive console

For the first part of this lesson, you can use the interactive console through a Command Prompt/Terminal (by opening a Command Prompt/Terminal and typing python) or through IDLE. Since IDLE’s interactive console is just a graphical interface wrapped around the regular Python console, you shouldn’t see any difference in function.

Before we get started, consider a few things about the interactive console:

  1. It has memory. Any variable or method defined in the console will exist and be accessible until the console is terminated. This allows us to type long scripts one statement at a time and keep the results of each statement at hand for the next;
  2. It can be terminated at any time by using the exit statement exit();
  3. If the console is busy with a task, you can force termination using the Control/Command key and C, this is called a keyboard interrupt;
  4. Any statement that produces output will print out its output on the line following a statement;
  5. You can view the contents of a variable at any time by using its name as a statement.

1.1 Mathematical operations

The most basic thing the interactive console can do it basic arithmetic. If you use any mathematical operation as a statement, you should see the results printed below. All the basic operators taught in algebra are valid. As such, we can experiment and produce the following:

Various arithmetic operations in the console

Note that just like in classical algebra, you can use parentheses to group operations together, and chained operations such as (1 + 1) * (12 * 50) can be composed from simpler ones.

2. Variables

What differentiates the interactive console from a simple pocket calculator is its ability to store and manipulate different kinds of data. To achieve this, we will use variables. Variables in Python are no different from their algebraic counterparts: they act as a symbolic replacement for data. This means that once defined, a variable can be inserted in other operations and behave as if you had inserted the data is contains.

Before we create our own, however, we should define a few basic data types available in Python: these data types will determine what kind of data is stored in a variable and what sort of operations we can apply on said variable.

2.1 Primitives and Objects

Python data types can be separated into two classes: primitives and objects. The separating criterion is fairly simple: primitives can be represented by a single numerical value while objects require a bigger structure stored in memory, to which the variable points. Below are the three main primitive types we will be using most of the time:

Data type Definition Example values
int Integer values 1, -1, 2000000
float Floating-point values 1.1, -1.5
boolean True or false binary values True, False

In addition to these types, we need to define at least one object type: the string. Strings are collections of characters and can contain single characters, words, sentences and even entire books.

Data type Definition Example values
str Strings, any set of character surrounded by single or double quotation marks "Hello, world!", "A"

2.2 Operations on primitives

All of the arithmetic operations we have experimented with in the [first section] of this lesson are applicable to any primitive. In the case of True and False (boolean values), those will be interpreted as 1 and 0 respectively. As such, the following is possible:

Arithmetic using boolean values

This outlines what we said earlier: any primitive value can be represented as a number.

2.3 Operations on objects

Operations on objects are a bit trickier. Because objects are complex structures, no two object types have the same operations! Because object operations are defined on a case by case basis, we’ll look at the one object we considered so far: the string.

While strings cannot be divided or subtracted from one another, two operations exist:

Operation Definition
+ Concatenation, or the union of two or more strings
* Multiplication, or the act of repeating strings

The first operation, concatenation, allows you to make longer strings out of shorter ones. This means that given three strings, we can use the + operator to form a new longer one that represents the sum of the three:

Concatenating strings

The same way, using the * operator will duplicate and concatenate strings. For example, typing "hello" * 2 would result in the string "hellohello"; the initial string would be repeated twice, and the repetitions concatenated.

2.4 Operations and data types

The operations defined earlier only apply between items of the same type (either primitive or object). As such, while you can add a float to an int, you cannot concatenate a string to a number directly as either element has a different definition of what the operation + should do. To solve this issue, you can convert one data type to the other, when possible. To do so, we will introduce three functions (also called methods):

Method Definition
str(x) If possible, converts the value x to a string. This would, for example, convert the integer 1 to the string "1".
int(x) If possible, converts the value x to an integer.
float(x) If possible, convers the value x to a float.

These conversions are limited: only strings representing numbers can be converted to proper numbers using float(x) and int(x), but any float, integer or boolean can be converted to a string using str(x).

We can use these functions to combine data of different types. Using this, we could write the following statement:

"Hello! I am " + str(27) + " and I like Python."

Without the type conversion, an error would occur:

TypeError during concatenation

2.2 Creating and modifying variables

As we’ve seen in the previous sections, we can easily manipulate raw data in the interactive console. However, one large issue that stops us from going forward is data persistence. While we can apply operations on numbers and strings, we have yet to save anything to memory! This is where variables come in. As we said earlier, variables are symbolic replacements for data. Once defined, a variable and the data is contains can be substituted in any other statement.

Python being a soft-typed language, we do not need to handle which data type each variable stores; the interpreter will handle that seamlessly as we use our variables. This results in a very simple model for the definition of variables:

my_variable = some_value
